awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Career Development and Professional Trajectories of Disadvantaged Students in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this work is to explore the career development and professional identity trajectories of a marginalized group to pursue a career in engineering. Degrees in engineering are an established pathway to a stable, well-paying career, but engineering has historically been predominantly a white, heterosexual, male dominated field. Thus, in order to develop a diverse and well-prepared engineering workforce, there is a critical need for additional research into educational experiences, as well as the professional and academic outcomes of marginalized students as they strive to become competent professionals in the workforce of tomorrow. Companies also stand to benefit from more inclusive environments, as diverse environments contribute significantly to improved engineering outcomes by promoting innovation.

Through a series of quantitative surveys and qualitative interviews, this project will first assess the prevalence of engineering disciplines as a career path for marginalized students (e.g., LGBTQ students), and investigate their personal and professional development trajectories across disciplines. In subsequent surveys, the researchers will explore in greater depth the professional and personal identity development experiences of the marginalized students, with specific focus on perceptions of inclusiveness vs. experiences of alienation/marginalization and barriers vs. supports for career development in engineering. This study will grow the knowledge in multiple fields, particularly psychology, engineering education, and various engineering disciplines. The results of this work will be shared with educators and engineers through professional societies, scholarly publications, and participation at conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the career development and professional identity trajectories of undergraduate LGBTQ+ students in engineering. In the first Phase of data collection, survey data were collected from 414 college students representing the full range of academic disciplines, assessing identity development processes in the domains of academic/vocational identity and sexual identity. Four patterns of identity configuration emerged in the broad sample of LGBTQ+ college students, with no differences observed across students from different academic disciplines. The largest group of students ? Sexual Identity Focused (39.85%) - reported more mature identity development in the domain of sexual identity, relative to vocational identity. The second largest group of students ? Intersectional Diffused (28.98%) -remained at the beginning stages of development regarding both vocational and sexual identity. The third profile of identity development ? Intersectional Acheived, those who demonstrated advanced, mature identity status in both domains, was represented by 18.35% of students. Finally, 12.31% of students were identified as Vocational Identity Focused, with lower development in the domain of sexual identity. Patterns of identity development were significantly related to LGBTQ+ school climate, experiences of discrimination, and self-efficacy with regard to career decision making.

A second round of survey data collection focused explicitly on the experiences of 166 LGBTQ+ students in university engineering programs. Analyses focused on tests of the Minority Stress Model (Meyer, 2003), which posits a pathway from distal stressors that are unique to marginalized populations (i.e., discrimination, harassment, and rejection) to proximal stressors the are internalized by members of minority groups (e.g., internalized homonegativity, pressure to conceal one?s identity) to negative social and psychological outcomes. In this sample, we observed clear support for the minority stress model, with regard to vocational identity development for engineering LGBTQ+ students. Reports of discrimination in work/school settings were significantly related to more negative perception of one?s identity as an LGBTQ+ person, which in turn was related to lower levels of vocational identity development and confidence.

Finally, a sample of 10 students in engineering programs agreed to participate in follow up 1:1 interviews to explore their experiences as LGBTQ+ students in engineering programs. Students shared experiences of marginalization and exclusion in their programs, highlighting experiences of invisibility in programs that prioritized productivity and defined ?professionalism? as a mandate to avoid any form of personal expression or self-advocacy. However, students also provided a range of recommendations for universities in general and engineering educators specifically, based on their lived experiences of both hardship and nurturing/support.

 

Meyer, I. H. (2003). Prejudice, social stress, and mental health in lesbian, gay, and bisexual populations: conceptual issues and research evidence. Psychology of Sexual Orientation and Gender Diversity, 1, 3-26.

 

Manuscripts submitted for publication (* indicates student author)

 

*Parmenter, J. G., Galliher, R. V., & Berke, R. (under revision). Configurations of sexual and vocational identity processes among sexual minority college students.  

 

*Pradell, L., *Parmenter, J. G., Galliher, R. V., & Berke, R. (under revision). LGBTQ+ engineering students' recommendations for sustaining and supporting diversity in STEM.

 

*Pradell, L., *Parmenter, J. G., Galliher, R. V., *Rowley, L., *Turner, K., & Berke, R. (under review). Master and alternative narratives in the stories of transgender and non-binary engineering students.

 

*Pradell, L., *Parmenter, J. G., Galliher, R. V., & Berke, R. (under review). LGBTQ+ students in engineering spaces: A framework of identity-related experiences.

 

*Turner, K., Galliher, R.V., *Pradell, L., *Parmenter, J. G., and Berke, R. (in preparation). Test of the minority stress model: Vocational identity processes among LGBTQ+ students in engineering.  

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2023
Modified by: Ryan Berke
